title: 104_hr1683
content: The Act titled "Public Employee Pension Plan Liability Act of 1995" allows for civil enforcement of public employee pension plan terms. The "Public Employee Pension Plan Liability Act of 1995" allows participants or beneficiaries to bring civil actions against the plan to recover benefits, enforce rights, or obtain equitable relief. The burden of proof is on the plaintiff to prove their case by a preponderance of the evidence. In actions brought under the "Public Employee Pension Plan Liability Act of 1995," a plaintiff must prove their case by clear and convincing evidence for plans subject to review by qualified boards. Public employee pension plans are treated as persons and can be sued accordingly. State courts and federal district courts have concurrent jurisdiction over such actions. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction to grant relief in actions brought under this section, regardless of the amount in controversy or the parties' citizenship. Venue for such actions can be in any district of the State where the plan is administered, where the breach occurred, or where a defendant resides. The court may award attorney's fees and costs in its discretion for actions brought under this section. The court may award attorney's fees and costs to the prevailing party in the action. SEC. 3. REVIEW BY QUALIFIED REVIEW BOARDS OF CHANGES IN EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS. A public employee pension plan must have changes in employer contributions reviewed by a qualified review board. The board's membership and powers are determined by the law of the principal State. The board consists of 3 members with expertise in pension fund management. The board overseeing changes in employer contributions for a public employee pension plan consists of 3 members with expertise in fund management. Members are appointed by the Governor, selected by plan participants, and jointly chosen by the Governor and a representative of participants. Each member has 1 vote and serves for equivalent terms as prescribed by state law. The Governor establishes a certified list of pension experts for selection purposes. The board overseeing public employee pension plans must maintain a certified list of pension experts for review purposes. The board's powers include approving or disapproving changes to the plan. The board overseeing public employee pension plans must review and approve any changes to the plan that affect employer contributions. This review can be requested by one-third of trustees or the head of an employee organization representing at least 20% of active participants. The board must be qualified under state law to conduct such reviews. The board must approve any changes to the public employee pension plan affecting employer contributions, with the change taking effect only upon board approval. SEC. 4. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS. This Act does not change state laws unless they relate to public employee pension plans covered by this Act. State causes of action in state courts are not affected. The term "administrator" in this Act refers to the board of trustees or retirement board responsible for a plan, or the plan sponsor if no specific person is designated. The term "beneficiary" refers to a person designated by a participant or by the terms of a plan. A participant or public employee pension plan may designate a beneficiary entitled to benefits. An employee is anyone working for an employer making contributions to the plan. An employee organization is a union or group dealing with pension plans or employment matters. The term "employer" in a public employee pension plan refers to the government of a State or political subdivision, agencies, or instrumentalities of the government, and employer contributions are defined as any contribution to the plan excluding those made by participants. An employer representative can be a group or association of employers involved in plan-related activities. The term "public employee pension plan" refers to any plan, fund, or program established by an employer, employer representative, or employee organization to provide retirement income to employees. The term "public employee pension plan" provides retirement income to employees or defers income for periods extending beyond termination of employment, regardless of contribution or benefit calculation methods. The term "principal State" refers to the state with the largest percentage of plan participants, and "Governor" refers to the official in charge of the principal State's public employee pension plan. The term "participant" refers to individuals eligible for benefits from a public employee pension plan. The term "person" includes various entities like states, corporations, and employee organizations. The term "plan sponsor" pertains to employers in charge of plans for their employees. The term "plan year" refers to the calendar, policy, or fiscal year on which a plan's records are kept. The term "State" includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 applies to public employee pension plans in the United States, including the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and Guam. The Act does not apply to certain employee benefit plans exempt under specific sections or unfunded plans for select management or highly compensated employees. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 applies to public employee pension plans in the United States, including certain exempt plans for management or highly compensated employees, severance pay arrangements, coverage agreements under the Social Security Act, and individual retirement accounts. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 applies to various retirement plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including individual account plans, annuity contracts, state deferred compensation plans, and plans for workers' compensation or disability insurance compliance. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 applies to various retirement plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The provisions of this Act will be effective for plan years starting on or after January 1, 1996.
